key_title: Key to the species of Erigeron

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Erigeron
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Erigeron. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Outer florets with ligules 1.5–5 mm long
Outer florets with a minute oblique limb or ligules up to 1 mm long

Plants sprawling, usually freely branched with numerous capitula; at least some leaves usually deeply toothed or lobed; cypselas c. 1 mm long, with pappus c. 2 mm long; garden-escaped plant of disturbed sites

Plants unbranched above (but sometimes with branching rhizomes), with leaves rosetted or crowded at base and capitula solitary, on erect peduncles, or plant stiffly erect, with capitula in narrowly corymbose inflorescence; native species of alps
Involucral bracts glabrous or almost so; capitula usually 3–4 mm long
Involucral bracts hairy; capitula usually 4–6(–12) mm long
Outer florets with a minute oblique limb; involucral bracts lanceolate or narrowly triangular, brown inside when reflexed at maturity
Outer florets with short ligules; involucral bracts narrow, linear to narowly lanceolate, the inner at maturity pale on most of the inner face
Stems coarsely pilose or hirsute (but not densely so); leaf-margins usually coarsely pilose; outer involucral bracts with a few hairs; bracts without a purplish spot at the apex
Stems glabrous or inconspicuously hairy; leaf margins with a few scattered long hairs at base, otherwise finely strigose; involucral bract usually glabrous, usually with a purplish spot at the apex
Capitula 4–5 mm long, numerous in a pyramidal panicle, inner involucral bracts mostly brown on the inner face at maturity

Capitula 5–6 mm long and numerous, or up to 12 mm long and rather few (to c. 35); panicle not usually pyramidal; inner involucral bracts mostly pale on the inner face at maturity (sometimes brown above but then with broad pale margins below)
Capitula c. 8–12 mm long, up to c. 35
